importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky earned international acclaim as the under-12 World Youth Chess Champion in November 2007, establishing himself as one of the country’s most promising young talents.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.
The New York Times hired Naroditsky as a chess columnist in 2022, marking a major milestone in his public engagement with chess education.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame from 2007 to 2025 captures Naroditsky’s rise from youth champion to a globally influential chess educator and commentator.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29.
He earned the title of grandmaster before high school and won multiple national championships early in life.
Naroditsky became a prominent chess educator and commentator, publishing a chess manual at age 14 and contributing to Chess Life and the New York Times.
He built massive online followings on YouTube (nearly 500,000 subscribers) and Twitch (340,000 followers), where he livestreamed games and taught chess in an engaging, accessible way.
The International Chess Federation and the Saint Louis Chess Club publicly mourned his death, recognizing him as a beloved educator and community pillar.
A moment of silence was observed at the 2025 US Chess Championship in St. Louis in his honor.
The Charlotte Chess Center, where he served as head coach, confirmed his death and described him as a talented player, educator, and cherished community member.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster born in the San Francisco Bay Area, died at age 29, leaving behind a legacy as one of the most influential modern chess educators. He earned grandmaster status before high school, won multiple national youth championships, and rose to prominence through accessible online content on YouTube and Twitch, where he amassed over 500,000 subscribers and 340,000 followers. As a columnist for The New York Times and contributor to Chess Life, he helped popularize chess among the general public. Institutions such as the Charlotte Chess Center, Stanford University, and the International Chess Federation honored his contributions. A moment of silence was held at the 2025 US Chess Championship in St. Louis in his memory, underscoring his impact on both competitive and educational chess worldwide.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
